{{About|the new host and format of the radio show|the predecessor show hosted by Garrison Keillor|A Prairie Home Companion}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox radio show | show_name = Live from Here | image = File:2016-01-30CarlileJaroszThilePunchBrosAPHC.jpg | imagesize = 275px | caption = Chris Thile on [[mandolin]] (left of center), on ''APHC'' with guest vocalists Brandi Carlile (center), as well as [[Sarah Jarosz]] and the [[Punch Brothers]]. [[Fitzgerald Theater]], <!--30 January-->2016 | format = Music, comedy, storytelling (radio variety) | audio_format = | record_location = | runtime = 2 hours | starring = [[Chris Thile]], [[Rich Dworsky]], [[Punch Brothers]] [[Chris Eldridge]] and [[Paul Kowert]], [[Brittany Haas]], [[Sarah Jarosz]], [[Aoife O'Donovan]], Ted Poor, Serena Brook, [[Tim Russell]], [[Sue Scott (actress)|Sue Scott]], [[Fred Newman (actor)|Fred Newman]], [[Tom Papa]] | narrated = | opentheme = [[Radio Boogie]] | endtheme = | country = United States | language = English | home_station = [[Minnesota Public Radio]] | creator = | developer = | producer = | executive_producer = | syndicates = [[American Public Media]] | first_aired = October 15, 2016 | last_aired = | preceded_by = ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]]'' | num_episodes = | website = {{URL|http://livefromhere.org/}} | podcast = }} '''''Live from Here''''', formerly known as '''''A Prairie Home Companion with Chris Thile''''', is an American variety radio show known for its musical guests, especially folk and traditional musicians, tongue-in-cheek radio drama, and relaxed humor. Hosted by [[Chris Thile]], it airs on Saturday evenings and is usually recorded in front of a live audience at the [[Fitzgerald Theater]] in [[St. Paul, Minnesota]], although the show frequently goes on tour to [[New York City]] and other U.S. cities.
The show is derived from the historic ''[[A Prairie Home Companion| A Prairie Home Companion with Garrison Keillor]]'' (''APHC'') radio show. The original host, [[Garrison Keillor]], performed his final show in July 2016, and Thile's program began on October 15, 2016. Thile, an American virtuoso [[mandolin]]ist and singer-songwriter, had a two-decade history with ''APHC'' and is known for his work in the [[folk music|folk]] and [[progressive bluegrass]] groups [[Nickel Creek]] and [[Punch Brothers]]. After two unprecedented guest host spots in 2015, Keillor decided on his successor, featured Thile as host again in January–February 2016, and fully ceded his hosting role to Thile in the October 2016 performance at the [[Fitzgerald Theater]] in [[St. Paul, Minnesota]], continuing as the show's Executive Producer. Thile's new program presents expanded musical and comedic elements, retaining the template of the earlier program (e.g., its most recent acting and sound effect cast, and "sponsorships" from fictitious companies), but without such features as its earlier signature "Lives of the Cowboys" series and "News from Lake Wobegon" monologue. Reviews of the new program have been uniformly positive, focusing on the remaining familiar elements and on the new music and expanded musical focus brought by the new host.
On November 29, 2017, in the wake of allegations of misconduct against Keillor, American Public Media announced it would change the show's name.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2017/12/02/thile-addresses-keillor-news|title=Thile addresses Keillor news during New York show|last=Cox|first=Peter|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/11/29/garrison-keillor-former-host-of-prairie-home-companion-fired-by-minnesota-public-radio-for-alleged-improper-behavior.html|title=Garrison Keillor fired by Minnesota Public Radio for alleged improper behavior|last=Aiello|first=Chloe|date=2017-11-29|work=CNBC|access-date=2017-11-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mprnews.org/schedule/sat|title=Weekly On-Air Schedule {{!}} Minnesota Public Radio News|website=www.mprnews.org|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref> The new name of the show was announced as '''''Live from Here''''' live on the December 16, 2017, broadcast of the show.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.livefromhere.org/about/history|title=Live from Here: A Brief History|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref>
==Program host== {{Main article|Chris Thile}} Chris Thile, born in 1981, is an American virtuoso [[mandolin]]ist and singer-songwriter known for his [[folk music|folk]] and [[progressive bluegrass]] work in the trio [[Nickel Creek]] and the quintet [[Punch Brothers]].<ref name = NewsHourPerform13>{{cite AV media |people= Chris Thile, Chris & PBS NewsHour Staff |date= August 5, 2013 | title= Chris Thile Performs for the PBS NewsHour | trans-title= | medium= | language= |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UKU9pWWO-cA |access-date= December 1, 2016 | format= streaming video |time= |location= Arlington, VA |publisher= [[PBS NewsHour]] |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= [Quote:] Singer-songwriter and mandolinist Chris Thile performs a song for the PBS NewsHour. |ref= }}</ref><ref name = LeahyRS161014>{{cite journal | author = Leahey, Andrew | date = October 14, 2016 | title=Chris Thile on Tricky Task of Hosting 'Prairie Home Companion' | journal = [[Rolling Stone]] | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/features/chris-thile-talks-hosting-prairie-home-companion-w444955 | access-date=December 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name = AllMusicBio>{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/chris-thile-mn0000779146/biography|title=Chris Thile – Biography |author= [[Seida, Linda]] | work = AllMusic.com | access-date=February 13, 2015}}</ref><ref name=RiceBGBios>{{cite web |url=http://www.waynerice.com/bgbios/index.htm | authors = Rice, Wayne | date = July 24, 2008 | title=Welcome to Bluegrass Bios on the Web: T, Chris Thile (See also Nickel Creek) | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090321201702/http://www.waynerice.com/bgbios/index.htm |archivedate= March 21, 2009 | access-date = 30 November 2016 }}</ref> A child prodigy in music—self-described as "begging [his] parents for a mandolin from the time [he] was 2" and picking up the mandolin for the first time at the age of 5<ref name = MPRnews150722/>—Thile was one of a trio, with siblings [[Sara Watkins|Sara]] and [[Sean Watkins]], home-schooled California children in musical families, who formed the group [[Nickel Creek]] with Thile's father in 1989.<ref name = MPRnews150722/> An acoustic group, it continues as a trio to the present day (2016), with Thile's participation alongside his more recent acoustic quintet [[Punch Brothers]], both variously described using terms such as folk, progressive, bluegrass, "newgrass," and roots music.<ref name = Camp151125>{{cite journal | author = Camp, Zoe | date = November 25, 2015 | title=Punch Brothers: ''The Wireless'' EP [review] | journal = [[Pitchfork.com]] | url = http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21250-sarcosuchus-the-wireless-ep/ | access-date=December 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name = AllMusicBio/> Thile was awarded BBC's Folk Musician of the Year award in 2007, a MacArthur Fellowship "genius" award in 2012, and he has been nominated eight time for [[Grammy Award]]s, winning four, all Best Album awards, in different categories in 1997, 2002, 2013, and 2015 (Bluegrass, Contemporary Folk, Folk, and Contemporary Instrumental, respectively).<ref name = MPRnews150722/> [[Garrison Keillor]] has made known his personal opinion, that Thile is “the great bluegrass performer of our time.”<ref name=StreepNYT160927/> As well, others have observed that "[t]hough charming and cheery, Thile is by nature deeply competitive," and understands the business side of matters, and that the size of audiences that the show attracts will matter (see below).<ref name=StreepNYT160927/>
==History with ''APHC''== ===Guest performances=== {{expand section | with further brief, sourced descriptions of Thile's guest spots on the ''APHC'', before and after accepting the new position as host | small = no|date=December 2016}} Thile first performed with [[Garrison Keillor]] on ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]]'' in 1996, at age 15.<ref name = LeahyRS161014/><ref name = MPRnews150722>{{cite web|url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2015/07/22/chris-thile | title=5 Things You Didn't Know About Chris Thile | author = Miller, Ann Arbor | date = July 22, 2015 | work=MPRNews.org | access-date=November 30, 2016}}</ref> Over the next two decades, Thile returned to ''APHC'' eight times (according to the program's website),<ref name = MPRnews150722/> performing both as a solo artist and as a part of the groups [[Nickel Creek]] and the [[Punch Brothers]].{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} These guest appearances included performances at the programs home venue, the [[Fitzgerald Theater]], and at tour venues. Programs in which Thile participated that received press coverage or are otherwise sourced and noteworthy appear below.
* May 11, 1996—At [[The Fitzgerald Theater]] in [[St. Paul, Minnesota]]. In the ''Young Artists Showcase,'' Thile as a 15-years old.<ref>The references provided here state 14-years old, while the biography for Thile linked therein indicate 15-years old, as do all other sources cited in this article, and so the 15-years is the age stated.</ref> With regulars [[Tim Russell]], Chris Forth, [[Tom Keith]] and "[[The Guys All-Star Shoe Band]]" ([[Richard Dworsky]], [[Andy Stein]], [[Pat Donohue]], [[The Guys All-Star Shoe Band|Greg Hippen]], and [[The Guys All-Star Shoe Band|Arnie Kinsella]]), and other guests [[Kate MacKenzie]],<ref>See the Musicians section at the [[Radio Songs (album)]] article.</ref> [[Michael Cleveland]], and [[Seamus Egan]] and [[Solas (group)|Solas]] ([[Karan Casey]], [[John Doyle (musician)|John Doyle]], [[Winifred Horan]], and [[John Williams]]). Thile performed his songs ''Shadow Ridge'' (1992), ''What's the Matter with the Mill?'' (1996), and ''Faith River'' (1996), Keillor's song ''Greenland Whale Fisheries'' (1996), traditional and other songs (e.g., by [[Bill Monroe]] and MacKenzie) including ''Stoney Lonesome'', ''Mother the Queen of My Heart'' (1933), ''The Sweetest Gift A Mother's Smile'', ''Don't this Road look Rough and Rocky'', ''Wheel Hoss'', and ''[[Red River Valley (song)|The Red River Valley]]'' (1879), as well as the ''[[A Prairie Home Companion#Fictional sponsors|Powdermilk Biscuit Theme]]''.<ref name = prairiehome960511a>{{cite web | author=PublicRadio.org Staff | date= 2016 | title= A Prairie Home Companion, May 1996 | website= PublicRadio.org | url= https://prairiehome.publicradio.org/programs/1996/05/ | access-date= December 8, 2016 | quote = [Quote:] Live from The Fitzgerald Theater in St. Paul, Minnesota / It's the Young Artists Showcase with 14-year-old mandolin virtuoso Chris Thile, and 27-year-old Seamus Egan, Irish traditional musician, leading the quintet called Solas. }} See the preceding Note regarding Thile's age at this performance, appearing within this bullet point, above.</ref><ref name = prairiehome960511b>{{cite web | author=PublicRadio.org Staff | date= 2016 | title= A Prairie Home Companion, Saturday, May 11, 1996 | website= PublicRadio.org | url= https://prairiehome.publicradio.org/programs/19960511/960511MU.htm | access-date= December 8, 2016 | quote = [Quote:] Guests:Kate MacKenzie, guitar and vocals; Chris Thile, mandolin; Michael Cleveland, fiddle. Solas, featuring Seamus Egan: Seamus Egan, flute; Karan Casey, vocals; John Doyle, guitar, backing vocals; Win[i]fred Horan,[''sic.''] fiddle; John Williams, button accordion, concertina. }}</ref> * June 11, 2016—At the [[Ravinia Festival]], in [[Highland Park, Illinois]]. With the [[Punch Brothers]].{{verification needed|date=December 2016}}<ref>{{cite journal | author = Shefsky, Jay | date = June 9, 2016 | title = Chris Thile on Hosting ‘A Prairie Home Companion,’ Punch Brothers | journal = Chicago Tonight | via = WTTW.com | url = http://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2016/06/09/chris-thile-hosting-prairie-home-companion-punch-brothers | access-date = December 8, 2016 }}</ref>{{better source|date=December 2016}}
===Trial guest hosting=== [[File:2016-01-30ChrisThileAPHC.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Thile as guest host in January 2016]] {{expand section | with description of the remaining guest host spots prior to Thile's taking the ''APHC'' helm | small = no|date=December 2016}} When Keillor announced in November 2014 that he would absent himself from ''APHC'' for "only the second time in decades," he yielded the host's microphone to Thile for these guest host appearances.<ref name=StreepNYT160927>{{cite journal | author = Streep, Abe | date = September 27, 2016 | title=What’s ‘A Prairie Home Companion’ Without Garrison Keillor? | journal = [[The New York Times Magazine]] | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/02/magazine/whats-a-prairie-home-companion-without-garrison-keillor.html | access-date=December 1, 2016}}</ref> Thile began these appearances in 2015 and appeared a total of 4 times in the twelve months thereafter,{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}{{verification needed|date=December 2016}} the final two guest host spots being on January 30 and February 6, 2016.<ref name = KahnJB160108>{{cite journal | author = Kahn, Andy | date = January 8, 2016 | title = Paul Simon To Join Chris Thile On ‘A Prairie Home Companion’ | journal = JamBase.com | url = http://www.jambase.com/article/paul-simon-to-join-chris-thile-on-a-prairie-home-companion | access-date=December 1, 2016}}</ref>
The guest host appearances gave an indication of the type of crew that Thile would assemble, the kinds of guests he would attract, and the style in which he might host (see Format and Cast, below).<ref name = prairiehome161201/>{{better source|date=December 2016}} The hosted programs were on the following dates, and featured the following guest artists: * January 30, 2016, with Thile’s fellow [[Punch Brothers]] group members, with musical guests [[Brandi Carlile]], [[Ben Folds]] and [[Sarah Jarosz]].<ref name = KahnJB160108/> A special comedy spot was done by comedian [[Maria Bamford]].<ref name = MPRnews160412/>{{verification needed|date=December 2016}} * February 6, 2016, again with the Punch Brothers and Sarah Jarosz, with musical guests [[Paul Simon]] and [[Andrew Bird]],<ref name = KahnJB160108/> with special comedy again from [[Maria Bamford]].<ref name = MPRnews160412/>{{verification needed|date=December 2016}} Thile also covered [[Kendrick Lamar]]'s song about police brutality, ''[[Alright (Kendrick Lamar song)|Alright]],''{{when|date=December 2016}} to some social media criticism, about which he later said, “I would readily admit that my love of the song kind of blinded me,” and “I think it was a bad call.”<ref name=StreepNYT160927/> Thile is described as having "test dr[iven]" his idea for a newly-penned Song of the Week, with themes "tailored to current events," in his performance of "Omahallelujah," about [[Denver Broncos]] quarterback [[Peyton Manning]] during this episode.<ref name = LeahyRS161014/>
===Final Keillor program=== In 2015, Keillor announced that he would step down from hosting the program and designated [[Chris Thile]]<ref name="thile">{{cite web |url=http://www.avclub.com/article/garrison-keillors-reign-terror-over-americas-airwa-221476 |website=[[The A.V. Club]] |date=June 27, 2015 |last=Hughes |first=William |title=Garrison Keillor's Reign of Terror over America's Airwaves Finally Set to End}}</ref> as the new host. Keillor's final episode of the show was recorded live on July 1, 2016, at the [[Hollywood Bowl]] in California for an audience of 18,000 fans<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news |title=Garrison Keillor hosts final A Prairie Home Companion episode |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/jul/02/garrison-keillor-final-prairie-home-companion-episode |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=July 2, 2016 |access-date=January 8, 2017}}</ref> and broadcast the next day.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.startribune.com/sun-is-setting-on-garrison-keillors-time-on-lake-wobegon/382713261/ |newspaper=[[Star Tribune]] |location=Minneapolis |date=June 18, 2016 |last=Justin |first=Neal |title=Sun is setting on Garrison Keillor's time on Lake Wobegon}}</ref> Keillor retained artistic rights and trademark to the show's name as well as some distribution rights and rights to retail items connected with ''A Prairie Home Companion''. Thile made his debut as permanent host on October 15, 2016.
=== Name change === In November 2017 Minnesota Public Radio severed all business ties with former ''APHC'' host Garrison Keillor over unspecified "inappropriate behavior with an individual who worked with him."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/11/29/garrison-keillor-former-host-of-prairie-home-companion-fired-by-minnesota-public-radio-for-alleged-improper-behavior.html|title=Garrison Keillor fired by Minnesota Public Radio for alleged improper behavior|last=Aiello|first=Chloe|date=2017-11-29|work=CNBC|access-date=2017-11-29}}</ref> The Minnesota Public Radio website listed the show under the [[working title]] ''The Show with Chris Thile'', as the trademark for ''A Prairie Home Companion'' is held by Keillor, not MPR.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mprnews.org/schedule/sat|title=Weekly On-Air Schedule {{!}} Minnesota Public Radio News|website=www.mprnews.org|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref> Thile addressed the situation on the December 2 installment of the series,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/garrison-keillor-reportedly-fired-for-improper-behavior/460802703|title='I think I have to leave the country,' Keillor says after firing|last=Justin|first=Neal|date=29 November 2017|work=[[Star Tribune]]|accessdate=30 November 2017}}</ref> and Thile began using a new theme, "[[Radio Boogie]]".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/chris-thile-addresses-scandal-around-his-prairie-predecessor/461547363/|title=Chris Thile addresses scandal around his 'Prairie Home' predecessor Garrison Keillor|work=Star Tribune|access-date=2017-12-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.livefromhere.org/story/2017/12/09/rundown|title=Rundown - A Prairie Home Companion for December 9, 2017|access-date=2017-12-31}}</ref>
The show aired under the placeholder title of ''The Show with Chris Thile'' for the next two Saturdays. Finally, on December 16, Thile announced the show's new name as "Live from Here."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.livefromhere.org/story/2017/12/16/rundown|title=Rundown - Live From Here for December 16, 2017|access-date=2017-12-31}}</ref>
==New ''APHC'' format== {{expand section | the settled format for the new program, once further articles are published about its evolution and point of equilibrium | small = no|date=December 2016}} Thile has referred to the program that Keillor created as a "truly great wor[k] of art" and so "immortal," so that he would "keep using the template [Keillor] created to tell each other stories and to escape from our daily cares.<ref name = MPRnews160412>{{cite web|url=http://www.mprnews.org/story/2016/04/12/chris-thile-offers-glimpse-at-new-prairie-home | title=Chris Thile Offers Glimpse of the New Prairie Home | author = Wurzer, Cathy | date = April 12, 2016 | work=MPRNews.org | access-date=November 30, 2016}}</ref> Even so, Andrew Leahy of the ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' writes that Thile has had added to the mandate of "preserving the show's appeal" a further one of "revising its structure and broadening its reach to younger generations."<ref name = LeahyRS161014/> Hence, the program continues to present a variety of program elements, including music, and storytelling, comedic and otherwise (see following), but Thile has indicated some changes in direction, and others are noted in early reviews. Absent from the new program is the "Lives of the Cowboys" sketch,<ref name=APguardian160702>{{cite journal | author = AP Staff | via = Associated Press (AP) | date = July 2, 2016 | title = Garrison Keillor Hosts Final A Prairie Home Companion Episode | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/jul/02/garrison-keillor-final-prairie-home-companion-episode | journal = The Guardian | access-date = 30 November 2016 }}</ref> and the signature weekly "News from Lake Wobegon" monologues from Garrison Keillor; still present as of October 2016 are "old favorites" such as the program's faux sponsorship by Powdermilk Biscuits.<ref name = JohnsonCT161017>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/ct-garrison-keillor-prairie-new-host-ent-1018-20161017-story.html|title='A Prairie Home Companion' Without Keillor Remains a Comfortable Listen|first=Steve|last=Johnson|date=|work=chicagotribune.com|accessdate=November 30, 2016}}</ref>
As of the opening month of the program, the planned replacement for the Keillor monologue was a slate of appearances from standup comics, for instance, the Irish comedian [[Maeve Higgins]].<ref name = JohnsonCT161017/> New music from the host, and expanded music in general, have been noted as features of the new program.<ref name = MPRnews160412/><ref name = JohnsonCT161017/> Andrew Leahy of ''Rolling Stone'' offers as perspective, that{{quote|Perhaps the most crucial ingredient in Thile's radio-show-revision recipe is his Song of the Week. Every broadcast will feature a newly-penned composition, its lyrics and instrumental themes tailored to current events.<ref name = LeahyRS161014/>}} Thile has indicated that the musical variety of the premiere program (see below) will continue, with listeners to expect "roots-rockers, folksingers, jazz musicians, soul revivalists and bluegrass bands all taking the stage."<ref name = LeahyRS161014/>
==Cast and crew== {{expand section | other behind-the-mic/camera crew, from other published sources | small = no |date=December 2016}} In addition to Chris Thile, who will contribute originally composed music and performances on his various instruments, the musical and acting cast and crew consists of the following artists, as of 1 December 2016 (in credit order from the production page for the shows performers, where deeper autobiographies appear).<ref name = prairiehome161201>{{cite web | url= https://www.prairiehome.org/about/performers | title= A Prairie Home Companion with Chris Thile: Regular Performers and Cast | author=APM Staff | date= December 1, 2016 | website= PrairieHome.org| access-date= December 1, 2016 }}</ref> {{div col|colwidth=30em}} ===Musicians=== The following regular musicians and roles are reported:<ref name = prairiehome161201/> * [[Rich Dworsky]], "longtime Prairie Home Companion music director," also composing, arranging, and performing at keyboards.<ref name = prairiehome161201/> * [[Chris Eldridge]], [[Punch Brothers]] guitarist.<ref name = prairiehome161201/><ref name=AllMusicPunch>{{cite web| author = Ruhlmann, William | date = December 1, 2016 | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/crooked-still-mn0000332973/biography|title=Crooked Still - Biography & History | work=AllMusic.com | access-date = December 1, 2016 }}</ref> * [[Brittany Haas]], fiddler.<ref name = prairiehome161201/> * [[Sarah Jarosz]], singer-songwriter, duet partner of Aoife O'Donovan.<ref name = prairiehome161201/><ref name = AllMusicBio/><ref>Jarosz also is able to perform on mandolin, octave mandolin, guitar, and banjo. See APM Staff (December 1, 2016). "A Prairie Home Companion with Chris Thile: Regular Performers and Cast, ''op. cit.''</ref> * [[Paul Kowert]], [[Punch Brothers]] bass player.<ref name = prairiehome161201/><ref name=AllMusicPunch/> * [[Aoife O'Donovan]], singer-songwriter, duet partner of Sarah Jarosz.<ref name = prairiehome161201/><ref name = AllMusicBio/> * [[Ted Poor]], drummer.<ref name = prairiehome161201/> * [[Sean Tejaratchi]],
===Actors and sound effects=== The following are other regular performers and roles as reported:<ref name = prairiehome161201/> * [[Serena Brook]], actress and voice-over artist.<ref name = prairiehome161201/> * [[Tim Russell]], ''APHC'' veteran, voice actor and impressionist.<ref name = prairiehome161201/><ref>While the words "veteran" and "impressionist" are not used at this source, they are readily inferred from the description of his role (e.g., "does a better Ira Glass than Ira Glass"). See the reference cited.</ref> * [[Sue Scott (actress)|Sue Scott]], ''APHC'' veteran, actress and voice-over artist.<ref name = prairiehome161201/><ref>As above, summary terms "veteran" and actress" are derived from descriptions at the source. See the reference cited.</ref> * [[Fred Newman (actor)|Fred Newman]], ''APHC'' veteran, sound effects artist.<ref name = prairiehome161201/> {{div col end}}
==Broadcast information== Local public radio stations carry the weekly production of ''Live from Here with Chris Thile'' at one or more broadcast times, varying by station, and as of March 2018, the [[NPR Now]] channel on SiriusXM Satellite Radio carried the program on Saturday at 5 PM and Sundays at 11 AM, both Central Time (UTC – 6).<ref name = LiveFromHereListen>{{cite web | url = https://www.livefromhere.org/listen/ | title = Listening Information | author = Live from Here Staff | date = March 10, 2018 | work = livefromhere.org | access-date = March 10, 2018}}</ref><ref>Central Time is 6 hours behind Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). See {{cite web | url= https://www.timeanddate.com/time/zones/cst | title=CST – Central Standard Time (Time Zone Abbreviation) | author = Time and Date Staff | date = March 10, 2018 |work=TimeandDate.com | access-date = March 10, 2018}}</ref> The audio of the program also [[streaming media|streams]], live online, at ''livefromhere.org'' on Saturdays from 5-7 PM Central, and video streams are likewise available when the program broadcasts from their home venue, [[The Fitzgerald Theater]], or their 'home-away-from-home," [[The Town Hall]] in New York City.<ref name = LiveFromHereListen/> Streaming audio from each show posts following the Saturday broadcast at ''livefromhere.org'', as of March 2018 at 12 PM, Central Time on Sunday.<ref name = LiveFromHereListen/>
The entirety of programs are made available via [https://www.livefromhere.org/shows/ Live from Here]'s official website on Sunday at 12 PM Central Time (UTC - 6) following each Saturday broadcast. Highlights from the show, including Chris Thile’s “Song of the Week,” are available via [[RSS]], [[iHeartRadio]], [[iTunes]], [[Stitcher]], and [[TuneIn]].<ref name = LiveFromHereListen/>
==Comments on the changeover== In the announcement of the change in host for the program, [[American Public Media]] stated:{{quote|One of the most popular public radio programs will begin a new chapter this fall as musician Chris Thile takes over for Garrison Keillor as the new host of A Prairie Home Companion, bringing a fresh approach to an audience favorite. Beginning on October 15, 2016, Thile will host a 30-week season, including live broadcasts, produced shows and repeats on public radio stations nationwide.”<ref name = APHC150203 >{{cite web | url= http://prairiehome.org/special-guest-host-chris-thile-february-2015/| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304084457/http://prairiehome.org/special-guest-host-chris-thile-february-2015/ |archive-date= March 4, 2016 | title= A Prairie Home Companion with Garrison Keillor: Special Guest Host Chris Thile, February 7 and 14, 2015| author=APM Staff | date= February 3, 2015| website= prairiehome.org| access-date= 2015-04-03 }}</ref><ref name = APM_APHCwCT_Press>{{cite web | author=APM Staff | date= November 30, 2016 | work=PrairieHome.org | title=Press Room, Press Clips | url=https://www.prairiehome.org/about/press | access-date=November 30, 2016}}</ref>}} Keillor, who had made various statements regarding retirement in the past, was described in June 2016 as being "fairly serious this time," and he is quoted as saying “Chris is my man, and I’m eager to stay home and read books.”<ref name = HughesAVClub160626>{{Cite journal |author =Hughes, William |date=June 26, 2015 |title=Garrison Keillor's Reign of Terror over America's Airwaves Finally Set to End | journal =[[The A.V. Club]] | url=http://www.avclub.com/article/garrison-keillors-reign-terror-over-americas-airwa-221476 | access-date = 30 November 2016}}</ref> Elaborating further, Keillor wrote to Abe Streep of ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]'', indicating that Thile's adventurous nature—alongside his high esteem for “the great bluegrass performer”<ref name=StreepNYT160927/>—were reasons for his consideration as Keillor's replacement, which would be tested via a trial run of guest host appearances in January–February 2016;<ref name=StreepNYT160927/> Keillor wrote,{{quote|I came to this decision myself, without talking to another soul about it… I could’ve held meetings, commissioned studies, appointed a task force, and six months later the task force would’ve concluded that the show could not go on. Well, I say it can and it should. And I decided it should return to its roots as a musical variety show and grow from there.<ref name=StreepNYT160927/>}} Keillor went on to write about Thile, “He takes big chances… He can be a chameleon, he can swim in every event, and for all his brilliance, nobody sounds better singing old American songs than he. Nobody.”<ref name=StreepNYT160927/>
Thile, in discussing the changeover with Minnesota Public Radio, indicated that he would continue to write new musical material, as he has in initial programs since his debut as host: "I would like to write something new every week... I've written a new song for each show. I want to keep doing that. It's so much fun."<ref name = MPRnews160412/> In addition, he has highlighted comedy as an element for the new show, noting the success of appearances of comedian [[Maria Bamford]] in shows he had hosted early in 2016 which gave "five or six minutes of hilarity." With regard to [[story telling]], he noted the success of an appearance by actor [[Ed Helms]], indicating that the new ''APHC'' will "have that kind of thing going on." When asked about future on-air material from show originator and current executive producer [[Garrison Keillor]], Thile replied, "He's such an amazing writer that if he comes up with an idea that would be good for the show… I imagine we'll get a script here and there."<ref name = MPRnews160412/>
===APM business strategy=== While much media focus during the changeover is on the artistry and styles associated with Keillor and Thile, ''APHC'' and [[American Public Media]] (APM) are businesses as well; at its peak, the original ''APHC'' radio program had garnered in excess of four million weekly listeners, and [[Rivertown Trading Company]], the purveyor of ''APHC''-themed products, was sold in 1998 by Minnesota Public Radio for US $120 million.<ref name=StreepNYT160927/> Sensitive to the potential loss of audience with the change at the helm of the show—Thile has said that he knows he will lose some listeners devoted to Keillor, stating that his “goal is to lose one million… and add two.”<ref name=StreepNYT160927/>—the program's distributor, American Public Media, has indicated its intent to ease listeners completely away from experiencing the earlier [[Garrison Keillor|Keillor]] format by "mix[ing] in" more than a dozen of the new ''APHC'' programs with Thile, alongside a set of reruns where Keillor is at the helm.<ref name = JohnsonCT161017/>
==Critical response== {{expand section | broader, well-sourced responses to the show | small = no|date=December 2016}} Writing for the ''Chicago Tribune,'' Steve Johnson notes that the new program "still rel[ies] heavily on an air of authenticity derived from its Minnesota locale, [but] now leans a little more toward music," and "away from storytelling."<ref name = JohnsonCT161017/> Johnson concludes that the program remains "an easy, graceful listen" featuring "a killer musical repertoire in the Americana tradition," and "humor ranging from corny to cutting."<ref name = JohnsonCT161017/>
==Show history highlights== {{expand section | highlights of the first shows, and thereafter, periodic additions of highlights when individual shows garner media attention (and therefore published description and comment) | small = no |date=December 2016}} Thile's first ''A Prairie Home Companion with Chris Thile'' took place on October 15, 2016 at the [[Fitzgerald Theater]] in St. Paul.<ref name=Bream20161015>{{cite news |authors = Bream, Jon |url=http://www.startribune.com/chris-thile-seems-right-at-home-as-new-host-of-a-prairie-home-companion/397212461/#1 |title=Chris Thile Seems Right At Home As New 'Prairie Home Companion' Host |work=[[Star Tribune]] |date=October 15, 2016 |access-date=2016-10-16 }}</ref> Thile's opening program featured [[Jack White]] and [[Lake Street Dive]] as musical guests, and a new Song of the Week.{{clarify|date=December 2016}}<ref name = LeahyRS161014/>

{{Infobox play | name = Mankind | image = mankind.jpg | image_size = | caption = A page from the Macro Manuscript, the only known source for ''Mankind'' | writer = Unknown | chorus = | characters = Mercy
Mischief
Newguise
Nowadays
Nought
Mankind
Titivillus | mute = | setting = | premiere = {{Circa|[[1470 in literature|1470]]}} | place = [[East Anglia]] | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = | genre = [[Morality play]] | web = }}'''''Mankind''''' is an English [[medieval]] [[morality play]], written {{Circa|[[1470 in literature|1470]]}}. The play is a moral [[allegory]] about Mankind, a representative of the human race, and follows his fall into sin and his repentance. Its author is unknown; the manuscript is signed by a monk named Hyngham, believed to have transcribed the play. ''Mankind'' is unique among moralities for its surprising juxtaposition of serious theological matters and colloquial (sometimes obscene) dialogue. Along with the morality plays ''[[Wisdom (play)|Wisdom]]'' and ''[[The Castle of Perseverance]]'', ''Mankind'' belongs to the collection of the [[Folger Shakespeare Library]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] as a part of the [[Macro Manuscript]] (so named after 18th century owner [[Cox Macro]]). ==Date and provenance== In his critical edition of the play published by the [[Early English Text Society]] in 1969, Eccles argues for a date between 1465 and 1470. Wickham, in his Dent edition of 1976, agrees, finally settling on 1470.Wickham (1976, 1, 7). Similarly, Lester, in his [[New Mermaids]] edition of 1981, offers between 1464 and 1471.Lester (1981, xiv). Baker and, following his suggestion, Southern agree on a date of 1466.Southern (1973, 23). These arguments are based upon references to coinage in the playtext, specifically the "royal" and the "angel", which were minted between 1465 – 1470. The poem certainly dates from the reign of [[Edward IV of England]], and likely has an [[East Anglia]]n provenance; it was likely "intended to be performed in the area around Cambridge and the environs of Lynn in Norfolk."Walker (2000, 258-59). This is evidenced by numerous local place names dispersed throughout the play, including that of [[Bury St Edmunds]], significant for being the home of two former owners of the play: Thomas Hyngman (15th century) and Cox Macro (18th century).Ashley, introduction to ''Mankind'' Like ''Wisdom'', ''Mankind'' bears a Latin inscription by the monk Thomas Hyngman and the phrase (translated), “Oh book, if anyone shall perhaps ask to whom you belong, you will say, “I belong above everything to Hyngham, a monk.” Eccles, pp. xxviii Similarities between this hand and the text of the play lead scholars to believe that Hyngman transcribed the play.Beadle, pp. 318 However, several textual oddities likely derive from Hyngman's miscopying of the text because he was unfamiliar with it, so scholars do not credit Hyngman with authorship. Along with ''The Castle of Perseverance'' and ''Wisdom'', Hyngman's ''Mankind'' was acquired by the Reverend Cox Macro in the early 18th century. Macro bound them together somewhat arbitrarily, along with three other non-dramatic manuscripts. Early 19th-century owner Henry Gurney separated ''The Castle'', ''Wisdom'', and ''Mankind'' from the other manuscripts and bound them together as a collection in a separate volume. In 1936, the [[Folger Shakespeare Library]] purchased this manuscript at a [[Sotheby's]] auction for 440 pounds.Eccles, p. vii ==Synopsis== The play is a [[Morality play|moral]] [[allegory]] about Mankind, a representative of the human race, and follows his fall into sin and his repentance. The audience is instructed in the proper Christian life by watching Mankind's fall and redemption. The play begins with Mercy, who instructs the audience in how they should behave but is soon interrupted by Mischief (whose name indicates, in fifteenth-century English, something much more serious than the 'prank' it means now). Mischief mocks Mercy's preaching. A page is then missing in the manuscript. When the play resumes, Mischief has departed and New Guise (i.e., 'Fashion), Nowadays (i.e. 'living for today') and Nought (i.e. 'nothingness') are on stage. They continue the mockery of Mercy. After their exit, Mercy again addresses the audience, explaining why the three are evil and urging the audience to not follow their example. Mankind enters, and addresses the audience, introducing himself. He is a farmer, and is resolved to live a virtuous life. Mercy instructs Mankind about how to continue in this goal, warning him specifically about Mischief, New Guise, Nowadays and Nought. But Mankind has to stand against temptation on his own, and so Mercy leaves. New Guise, Nowadays and Nought return to tempt Mankind. First, they encourage the audience to join in with a scatological song. Then they turn their attention to Mankind, but he successfully resists their enticements and beats them off with his spade. Mischief returns and conspires with New Guise, Nowadays and Nought to bring in a greater devil, [[Titivillus]]. But first, they demand that the audience pay money before they can see Titivillus. When the audience does so, Titivillus enters, and begins immediately making Mankind's life difficult. The audience can see him, but he is invisible to Mankind. He hardens the ground, making it hard to farm. He steals Mankind's seed and spade. He induces a need to urinate. He distracts him from his prayers. Finally Mankind becomes so frustrated that he gives up and goes to sleep, and Titivillus whispers to him that Mercy is dead. Through his scene, Titivillus implores the audience to keep silent and watch him, which makes the audience complicit in his actions. Thus deluded, Mankind rejects Mercy and goes to join New Guise, Nowadays and Nought. But now their full evil is revealed. Mischief has been in jail, and has escaped, robbed the jailer, and raped his wife. New Guise has narrowly escaped hanging. Nowadays has robbed a church. The three have Mankind swear vows to join their gang, vows which also show their depravity—to be a highway robber, to seduce women, to 'rob, steal, and kill as fast as you may go' (708). When they leave, Mercy returns to plead with the audience about the unreliability of Mankind, and to pray for his redemption. The three reveal to Mankind that Mercy is not really dead, and tempt him to kill himself rather than face Mercy. But Mercy chases them away. The final struggle for Mankind's redemption is with himself. Mercy tells him all that he must do to be forgiven is to ask, but Mankind finds this difficult and raises a series of objections. The theology of the ending focuses on perseverance, on living as a Christian even while continuing to sin, even while trying not to, and having to repeatedly ask for mercy for those offences. Mankind finally accepts Mercy, and then promptly tries to blame the devils for his problems, but Mercy reminds him that he warned Mankind about them. For the play ends with Mercy addressing the audience again, exhorting them to repentance. ==Themes== Like other moralities, ''Mankind'' dramatizes the struggle over humanity between the forces of good and evil. Within this larger thematic structure, scholars have been fascinated by the comedic and potentially subversive tone of the play. The play is interested in the humor of transgression – five out of seven speaking roles are comic [[villain]]s, making ''Mankind'' the lightest and most colloquial of the Macro plays.Spivack, p. 123 At the same time, the play places a remarkable emphasis on language. Greene argues that Titivillus and the vices under his command reduce Mankind to the level of a dumb beast, lost and on the brink of damnation, by drawing him into their perverse, topsy-turvy distortions of language.Greene, p. 77 In his introduction to Furnivall's edition, Pollard writes that the "low tone" of the play is due to its nature as an economic venture, since the tone appealed to the largely uneducated common audiences for whom players performed.Pollard, in the introduction to Furnivall's ''The Macro Plays'' Eccles notes that ''Mankind'' is the first English play to "mention gathering money from an audience".Eccles, p. xlii Indeed, the play calls for a relatively significant amount of audience participation, as in the scene where New Guise, Nowadays and Naught cajole the audience into singing obscene carols with them. Ashley notes that in this way, "the audience itself is tricked into complicity with the devil’s machinations against Mankind." ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== *Ashley, Kathleen, ed. ''Mankind''. Michigan: Medieval Institute Publications, 2010. *Baker, Donald. ''The Date of Mankind.'' *Beadle, Richard and Piper, A.J. eds. "Monk Thomas Hyngham's hand in the Macro Manuscript", ''New Science out of Old Books: Studies in Manuscripts and Early Printed Books''. Aldershot: Scolar Press, 1995, pp. 315–41. *Bevington, David, ed. ''The Macro Plays: A Facsimile Edition with Facing Transcription.'' New York: Johnson Reprint, 1972. *Coldewey, John, ed. ''Early English Drama: An Anthology.'' New York: Garland, 1993. *Davenport, William. ''Fifteenth-Century English Drama: The Early Moral Plays and Their Literary Relations.'' Boydell & Brewer, 1982. *Eccles, Mark, ed. ''The Macro Plays.'' EETS o.s. 262. London: Oxford University Press, 1969. * Fifield, Merle. The Rhetoric of Free Will: The Five-action structure of the English Morality Play. Leeds Texts and Monographs New Series 5, University of Leeds School of English, 1974. *Furnivall, Frederick James and Pollard, Alfred William eds. ''The Macro Plays.'' For the Early English Text Society, 1904. *Gibson, Gail McMurray. ''The Theater of Devotion: East Anglian Drama and Society in the Late Middle Ages''. University of Chicago Press, 1994. *Greene, Darragh. '"Mysse-masche, driff-draff": Wittgenstein's Language-Games, Nonsense and the Grammar of the Soul in ''Mankind''.' ''Selim'', 22 (2017): 77-99. * Lester, G. A., ed. ''Three Late Medieval Morality Plays.'' The New Mermaids ser. London: A&C Black, 1981. *Riggio, Milla Cozart, ed. ''The Play of Wisdom: Its Texts and Contexts.'' New York: AMS Press, 1998. *Smart, Walter. ''Some English and Latin Sources and Parallels for the Morality of Wisdom''. 1912. * Spector, Stephen. "Paper evidence and the genesis of the macro plays", Mediaevalia 5: 217-32. 1979. *Spivack, Bernard. ''Shakespeare and the Allegory of Evil''. 1957. * Southern, Richard. ''The Staging of Plays Before Shakespeare.'' London: Faber, 1973. *Walker, Greg, ed. ''Medieval Drama.'' Oxford: Blackwell, 2000. * Wickham, Glynne, ed. ''English Moral Interludes.'' London: Dent, 1976. ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160724104710/http://research.uvu.edu/mcdonald/3610/mankind.html Full Middle English text with a modern translation] of the play from [[Utah Valley University]] *[http://tunemyheart.net/ant/?p=762 Examination of the professional aspects of Mankind] *[http://luna.folger.edu/luna/servlet/s/f18j03 Images of the Macro Plays] from the [[Folger Shakespeare Library]] Digital Image Collection {{Interludes}} [[Category:1470 plays]] [[Category:Medieval drama]] [[Category:Allegory]]

{{unsourced|date=July 2016}} {{notability|date=July 2016}} {| class="infobox" style="width: 21em; font-size: 90%; text-align: left" |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align:center; font-size: larger; background-color: #001;" | [[Tortured Souls|''Tortured Souls'']] character |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align:center; font-size: larger; background-color: #001; color: #ccc;" | Mongroid |- ! Gender: | [[Male]] |- ! Race: | Unknown |- ! Family: | [[Talisac]] (father) |- ! Status: | Alive |} The '''Mongroid''', a.k.a. '''The Second Coming''', is a [[Character (arts)|fictional character]] created by [[Clive Barker]] for the ''[[Tortured Souls]]'' toy line. Mongroid is the "son" (having been created through science) of [[Talisac|Dr. Talisac]]. Mongroid grew in Talisac's "[[womb]]" for seventeen weeks. Once born, it looked somewhat like Talisac, except being [[crab]]like and being forced to walk on four hands. A creature of pure instinct, it killed and devoured Talisac. It then went to the sewers to live. Mongroid's most notable feature is the large "mouth" growing from his [[abdomen]]. He was set to appear in the ''[[Tortured Souls: Animae Damnatae]]'' movie when it was . {{Tortured Souls}} [[Category:Clive Barker characters]] [[Category:Action figures]] {{Fict-char-stub}} {{Toy-stub}}

Trip Taylor | company = [[Dickhouse Productions]] | network = [[MTV2]] | first_aired = March 27, 2012 | last_aired = November 19, 2014 | opentheme = "[[The State of Massachusetts]]" by [[Dropkick Murphys]] | num_seasons = 4 | num_episodes = 32 | num_movies = | num_specials = | followed_by = ''[[Nitro Circus: The Movie]]'' | website = http://www.nitrocircus.com }} '''''Nitro Circus Live''''' (also known as '''''Nitro Circus Live: World Tour''''' in the final three seasons) is a [[reality television]] show. It follows [[Travis Pastrana]] and the [[Nitro Circus]] crew as they perform live on tour around the world.http://nitrocircus.com/nitro-circus-live-full-episodes/ ==Cast== ;[[Travis Pastrana]] :Title: [[Action sport|"Pro action sports athlete"]] :Pastrana is the Ringleader of the Nitro Circus Crew, is a pro [[Freestyle Motocross|FMX]] rider, rallycar driver, and [[NASCAR]] driver, and is usually the first to attempt any stunt involving dirt bikes or BMX bikes. ;[[Andy Bell (freestyle motocross rider)|Andy Bell]] :Title: [[motorcycle rider|"Washed-up motorcycle rider"]] :Former [[freestyle motocross|FMX]] rider. Bell holds a rivalry with Pastrana involving [[Big Wheel (tricycle)|Big Wheel]] tricycles stemming from the first episode of the series. ;[[Jolene Van Vugt]] :Title: [[Motocross|"Pro motocross racer"]] :Canadian Female Motocross Champion. She joins Pastrana in many stunts involving dirt bikes. Van Vugt took on more of a cheerleading role in the second season after breaking her arm and can be seen wearing a pink cast throughout the season. ;Jim DeChamp :Title: [[Mountain biking|"Pro mountain biker"]] :Pro mountain bike downhill racer and freestyle rider. He has been friends with Pastrana since childhood. They collaborate on many stunts together on the show. Became the first person to land a front-flip on a motorbike to dirt, as seen in the 7th episode of the first season. ;Erik Roner :Title: "[[Skiing|Pro skier]]/[[base jumper]]" :Pro extreme skier and base jumper. Roner is usually the first to attempt any stunt involving snow. He died in 2015 caused by a failed basejump. ;Tommy Passemante :Title: [[Construction worker|"Construction Worker"]] :Known by his nickname "Street Bike Tommy", given for a failed stunt in which he attempted to jump his [[Suzuki GSX-R]] motorcycle into the foam pit but overshot, breaking both his legs. He functions as the comic relief member of the crew, and is commonly employed for stunts that are the most dangerous and require the least amount of talent, known as "zero skill stunts". ;Greg Powell :Title: [[Travis Pastrana|"Travis' cousin"]] :Pastrana's Cousin. Going by the nickname "Special Greg", Powell is the all-around member of the team, and generally attempts any stunt on the show. He was the first person to land a "Special Flip" on a BMX bike. He was a wide receiver on the University of Maryland football team from 2003–06 and is currently an over-the-wall crewman for Pastrana in NASCAR.{{cite web |url=http://www.umterps.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/powell_greg00.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317003953/http://www.umterps.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/powell_greg00.html |archivedate=March 17, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} ==Episodes== ===Season 1: (2012)=== Season 1 premiered on MTV2 on March 27, 2012 with back-to-back episodes and ended on May 16, 2012.http://www.mtv.com/shows/nitro_circus_live/series.jhtml The first season covers the crew's first ever tour and it begins with dates Down Under. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%" |- style="color:black" ! style="background: #4EE2EC;"|No. ! style="background: #4EE2EC;"|# ! style="background: #4EE2EC;"|Title ! style="background: #4EE2EC;"|Original air date |- {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=1 |EpisodeNumber2=1 |Title=The Tour Begins |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2012|3|27}} |ShortSummary=The cast and show stunts are worked out in California, then the crew travels to Australia to rehearse for the first show. |LineColor=4EE2EC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=2 |EpisodeNumber2=2 |Title=Showing Off in Sydney |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2012|3|27}} |ShortSummary= Injuries mount in Sydney and jeopardize the success of the tour and Wheelz lands the first wheel chair backflip. Also, the cast races V-8 Supercars and play rugby on their day off. |LineColor=4EE2EC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=3 |EpisodeNumber2=3 |Title=Travis Does it Again |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2012|4|3}} |ShortSummary= The tour moves on to Perth for show number six. Travis lands the first ever TP roll (720 flip) and adds it to the show and the dangers of tricycle jumping are explained. Also, the cast plays in the desert with motorcycles and off-road race machines. |LineColor=4EE2EC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=4 |EpisodeNumber2=4 |Title=You Can't Keep a Good Team Down |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2012|4|17}} |ShortSummary= In this episode, challenges of tour life are examined and the crew does some camel racing before performing in Adelaide. More injuries threaten the show and the cast visits Bilko's house for a BBQ. |LineColor=4EE2EC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=5 |EpisodeNumber2=5 |Title=Pushing the Limits |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2012|4|24}} |ShortSummary= In this episode, the cast performs their final Australian show in Melbourne at Rod Laver Arena. Travis attempts a motorcycle double back flip for the first time in four years and the whole crew pushes the limits. |LineColor=4EE2EC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=6 |EpisodeNumber2=6 |Title=Hello New Zealand |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2012|5|1}} |ShortSummary= In this episode, the crew faces the challenges of performing in outdoor stadiums, new cast members join the show, and they perform in Auckland for the first time. The crew does promotional work and races jet boats on their day off. |LineColor=4EE2EC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=7 |EpisodeNumber2=7 |Title=Nitro Makes History |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2012|5|8}} |ShortSummary=The crew travels to Wellington and the tour grind wears on the cast but they continue to push the limits. Wheelz lands the first front flip in a wheel chair. Day off activities include visiting Palm Beach and sky diving. |LineColor=4EE2EC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=8 |EpisodeNumber2=8 |Title=Time Flies |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2012|5|16}} |ShortSummary= The cast finishes their tour of New Zealand in Christchurch in front of the biggest crowd yet. New tricks are landed for the first time, [[Gregg Godfrey]] adds family members to the show, and everyone reflects on the tour's success. The crew rafts on their day off. |LineColor=4EE2EC }} |} ===Season 2: (2013)=== Season 2 covers the first European tour. It premiered on MTV2 April 9, 2013 and ended on May 28, 2013. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%" |- style="color:white" ! style="background: #002387;"|No. ! style="background: #002387;"|# ! style="background: #002387;"|Title ! style="background: #002387;"|Original air date |- {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=9 |EpisodeNumber2=1 |Title=We Finally Made It |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|4|9}} |ShortSummary= Four riders end up in the hospital as Travis Pastrana and the Nitro Crew head to Sweden to kick off their European tour. |LineColor= 002387 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=10 |EpisodeNumber2=2 |Title=Sweden & Hamburg: Chilling Out |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|4|16}} |ShortSummary= After such a hectic start to the tour, the cast take a few days off to indulge in all things arctic. From a bar and hotel made out of ice, to racing reindeer and dog sleds, to the first annual Nitro Circus Ice Sculpting Competition the crew take some time to "Chill Out" in Sweden. |LineColor= 002387 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=11 |EpisodeNumber2=3 |Title=Berlin & Dusseldorf |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|4|23}} |ShortSummary= Travis Pastrana and the Nitro Crew face their toughest challenge yet, 3 shows in 3 nights in front of sold out crowds in Germany. |LineColor= 002387 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=12 |EpisodeNumber2=4 |Title=Vienna: Red Bull Wings and Things |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|4|30}} |ShortSummary= Travis Pastrana and the Nitro Crew are broken but not beat as they head to Austria, home of Red Bull and one of the most action sports crazy countries in the world. |LineColor= 002387 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=13 |EpisodeNumber2=5 |Title=Just a Couple of Tourists |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|5|7}} |ShortSummary= Midway through their European tour, Travis Pastrana and the Nitro Crew go sightseeing in Prague, hit the go kart track, and pull off their best show in history for a sold-out crowd in Belgium. |LineColor= 002387 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=14 |EpisodeNumber2=6 |Title=The Big One |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|5|14}} |ShortSummary= Travis Pastrana and the Nitro Crew head to the Netherlands to perform in front of a massive crowd of 27,000, their largest show ever. But first, they hold an eating competition that leaves one of them bleeding. |LineColor= 002387 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=15 |EpisodeNumber2=7 |Title=London Calling |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|5|21}} |ShortSummary= Travis Pastrana and the Nitro crew head to London for a tension-filled show with the future of the tour at stake. But the injury bug strikes once again, leaving producers to scramble mid-show to rewrite the second half. |LineColor= 002387 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=16 |EpisodeNumber2=8 |Title=The End of the Road |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|5|28}} |ShortSummary= As Travis Pastrana and the Nitro Crew wrap up their first ever European tour with 2 shows in England, the tour's most inspirational performer suffers a serious injury, leaving unsung heroes to step up in his absence. |LineColor= 002387 }} |} ===Season 3: (2013–14)=== Season 3 premiered November 27, 2013 with back-to-back episodes and ended on January 7, 2014 on MTV2 with back-to-back episodes. The first two episodes covers moments from the first two seasons. Except for "Pastranaland", Season 3's episodes cover the crew's Asia tour as well as a couple stops in New Zealand. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%" |- style="color:white" ! style="background: #FF52A9;"|No. ! style="background: #FF52A9;"|# ! style="background: #FF52A9;"|Title ! style="background: #FF52A9;"|Original air date |- {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=17 |EpisodeNumber2=1 |Title=Epic Fails |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|11|26}} |ShortSummary= Countdown of the top 10 "epic fails". |LineColor=FF52A9 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=18 |EpisodeNumber2=2 |Title=Epic Wins |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|11|26}} |ShortSummary= Travis and the crew count down the top 10 moments in the show and on tour. |LineColor= FF52A9 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=19 |EpisodeNumber2=3 |Title=Hong Kong |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|12|3}} |ShortSummary= Dragon Boat racing; Kung Fu; handling king cobras; a typhoon hits as the guys are about to board a ferry |LineColor=FF52A9 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=20 |EpisodeNumber2=4 |Title=Macau |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|12|3}} |ShortSummary= The crew arrives on Macau, and is surrounded by distractions in the world's largest hotel. |LineColor= FF52A9 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=21 |EpisodeNumber2=5 |Title= New Zealand |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|12|10}} |ShortSummary= The crew does a few shows in New Zealand. |LineColor= FF52A9 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=22 |EpisodeNumber2=6 |Title= Pastranaland |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2013|12|17}} |ShortSummary= Travis hosts an event in the middle of the world tour. |LineColor= FF52A9 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=23 |EpisodeNumber2=7 |Title=Moscow |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|01|7}} |ShortSummary= The cast must do something that the production team promised would not happen again; Russia. |LineColor= FF52A9 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=24 |EpisodeNumber2=8 |Title=St. Petersburg |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|01|7}} |ShortSummary= The guys take on Chess Boxing, search for love and try local cuisine. |LineColor= FF52A9 }} |} ===Season 4: (2014)=== Season 4 premiered on October 8, 2014 with back-to-back episodes. The fourth season will cover the crew's first ever North American tour along in addition to several stops in Europe. The first episode debuted on the MTV2 app a week before the premiere aired. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%" |- style="color:black" ! style="background: #00FF32;"|No. ! style="background: #00FF32;"|# ! style="background: #00FF32;"|Title ! style="background: #00FF32;"|Original air date |- {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=25 |EpisodeNumber2=1 |Title= Boston; New York |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|10|8}} |ShortSummary= The tour performs for a crowd in the United States for the first time ever. |LineColor=00FF32 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=26 |EpisodeNumber2=2 |Title= Philadelphia; Pastranaland |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|10|8}} |ShortSummary= While in Philadelphia, Crum and Sheeny receive boxing lessons and remake the iconic scene from ''[[Rocky]]'' |LineColor=00FF32 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=27 |EpisodeNumber2=3 |Title= Canada; Detroit |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|10|15}} |ShortSummary= The Circus travels to Canada for the first time ever. Jolene performs for her audience in Ontario. |LineColor=00FF32 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=28 |EpisodeNumber2=4 |Title= Cleveland; Salt Lake City |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|10|22}} |ShortSummary= Travis suffers a surious injury during the tour's stop in Cleveland. |LineColor=00FF32 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=29 |EpisodeNumber2=5 |Title= Las Vegas; California; Arizona |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|10|29}} |ShortSummary= The crew hits the West Coast. "Streetbike" Tommy strips down for the "Thunder Down Under." |LineColor=00FF32 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=30 |EpisodeNumber2=6 |Title= Scandinavia |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|11|5}} |ShortSummary= The tour arrives in Scandinavia, immersing themselves in Nordic culture. Extreme sports not found in the U.S.. |LineColor=00FF32 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=31 |EpisodeNumber2=7 |Title= England |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|11|12}} |ShortSummary= The tour invades Britain and performs six shows in six nights. |LineColor=00FF32 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=32 |EpisodeNumber2=8 |Title= Scotland; Amsterdam |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|11|19}} |ShortSummary= A surprise performance from [[Danny MacAskill]], the Scottish mountain biker. |LineColor=00FF32 }} |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://nitrocircus.com/}} * [http://shop.nitrocircus.com/ Nitro Circus Official Store] * [http://nitrocircus.net/ Nitro Circus Fan Site] * [http://www.nitro-circus.co.uk/ Official Nitro Circus UK Store] * [http://www.mtv.com/ontv/dyn/nitro_circus/series.jhtml MTV: Nitro Circus] * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1414349/ Nitro Circus] at [[IMDb]] {{Nitro Circus}} {{MTV2 original programs}} [[Category:2012 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2012 American television series endings]] [[Category:2010s American comedy television series]] [[Category:2010s American reality television series]] [[Category:MTV2 television series]] [[Category:Sports entertainment]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Motorcycle television series]] [[Category:Television series by Dickhouse Productions]]

revision.text:
{{Cleanup|date=January 2012}} [[File:OTI Performing.jpg|thumb|411x411px|On Thin Ice performing an improv game at one of their shows.]] '''On Thin Ice, (OTI)''' is [[Harvard College]]'s oldest [[Improvisational comedy]] group. OTI specializes in short-form improvisational theater taking the form of various comedy games in the style of [[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (U.S. TV series)|Whose Line Is It Anyway?]]. == History == Founded in 1984 by Brigit Fasolino Vucic, On Thin Ice is Harvard's oldest improv troupe.<ref>[http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=89621]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2008/10/25/legally_bonded/|title='Legally' bonded|first=Megan|last=Tench|date=26 October 2008|publisher=|via=The Boston Globe}}</ref> Shows performed once every few weeks, are about 45 minutes long and depend on audience suggestions. OTI's constitution requires that they perform free on-campus shows. OTI is famous for their Trial By Fire show, a showcase for their newest members. Performed once each semester, the Trial By Fire show requires all new members, having only had one practice, to perform in every game. Additionally, they have competed in a number of short-form improv comedy competitions across the country and travel locally and nationally performing for numerous events and organizations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clarku.edu/offices/publicaffairs/news/press/2006/peapod.cfm|title=404 Error|date=17 November 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=135782|title=Lampy Comedy Night To Raise Funds for PBH - News - The Harvard Crimson|publisher=}}</ref> And every year, during the [[Harvard–Yale football rivalry|Harvard-Yale football game]] weekend, OTI performs with an improv troupe from [[Yale]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yaleherald.com/thebullblog/the-official-bullblog-harvard-yale-dictionary-2010-edition/|title=The Yale Herald|first=Lauren|last=Gibbons|publisher=}}</ref>
==Notable alumni== A number of notable individuals in the entertainment business have been past members of On Thin Ice. Among the early members were actor [[Christopher Liam Moore]], Producer-Writer [[Nick Davis (television and movie producer)|Nick Davis]], screenwriter [[Adam Barr]], and TV executive [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1184701/ Susanne Lieberstein Daniels], as well as Eric Ronis, Christian Bordal (formerly Christian Kanuth), Ashby Semple, Eric Oleson, Kristen Gasser and Betty Achinstein. Other members in the 1980s included Producer [[Daniel Zelman]] and novelist [[Arthur Phillips]]. [[Mike Roiff]] produced the 2007 film [[Waitress (film)]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1988698/|title=Michael Roiff|publisher=}}</ref> [[Rob Dubbin]] is a writer for [[the Colbert Report]].<ref>http://colbertuniversity.nofactzone.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=44&Itemid=59</ref> [[File:OTIPuddingPerfomance.jpg|thumb|413x413px|On Thin Ice sings the final note of a musical improv scene at the [[Hasty Pudding Theatricals|Hasty Pudding]]'s annual Fall Show. ]]
==See also== * [[Improvisational theatre]] * [[List of improvisational theatre companies]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.hcs.harvard.edu/~oti/ On Thin Ice]
[[Category:Harvard University]] [[Category:Improvisational theatre]] [[Category:American comedy troupes]]
{{US-theat-stub}} {{comedy-stub}}

{| class="infobox bordered" style="width: 25em; text-align: left; font-size: 95%;" |+ style="font-size: larger;" | '''Oxford University Society of Bibliophiles''' |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | [[File:OUSB Device.jpg|245px|center]] |- ! Founded | 1950 (restored 2008) |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | '''Society officers, [[Hilary Term]] 2016''' |-
|- ! Honorary President | [[Henry Woudhuysen]], [[Rector (academia)|Rector]], [[Oxford|Lincoln College]] |- ! Honorary Vice-President | Paul W Nash, [[Bodleian Library]] |- ! President | Daniel Fried, [[New College, Oxford|New College]] |- ! Vice-President | Elle Pfeffer, [[Worcester College, Oxford|Worcester]] |- ! Secretary | Simon Korneev, [[St Catherine's College, Oxford|St Catherine's]] |- ! Treasurer | Constanta Burlacu, [[Merton College, Oxford|Merton]] |- ! Senior Committee | Geri Della Rocca de Candal, Cristina Dondi, [[Colin Franklin (bibliographer)|Colin Franklin]], Giles Mandelbrote, Scott Mandelbrote, [[Richard Ovenden]], William Poole, Julia Walworth. |- | colspan="2" style="font-size: smaller;" | |}
The '''Oxford University Society of Bibliophiles''' is a [[book collecting]] and [[Bibliophilia|bibliophile]] club run by, and primarily for, students at [[Oxford University]]. It was founded in 1950 by a group of young bibliophiles headed by John Granger, Bent Juel-Jensen and R. John Rickett, and the first meeting was held in Hilary Term of 1951.<ref>Nash and Howes 2006, p. 11.</ref> For fifty years the Society held regular lectures, visits and other events during the University terms, and many of the leading [[Bibliography|bibliographers]], [[librarians]], book collectors, [[booksellers]] and other literary figures of the period spoke to the Society or hosted visits. Many of the Society's junior members went on to become prominent figures in the world of books, and some later served as senior members of the Society. One of the most influential members was [[John Hanbury Angus Sparrow|John Sparrow]], Warden of All Souls, who encouraged a love of books and manuscripts in a generation of students, and hosted a termly "Warden's Meeting"<ref>Davies et al. 1977.</ref> at which members were encouraged to bring items from their own libraries to pass round and say a few words about; the tradition of the "Warden's Meeting" continued after 1986, when the Warden himself was too ill to host the meetings and, indeed, after his death in 1992. Another of the Society's traditions was the quality of the termly programme cards, often produced by the leading printers and [[private presses]] of the age, including the [[Oxford University Press|Oxford]] and [[Cambridge University Press|Cambridge]] University Presses, the [[Rampant Lions Press]], the [[Samson Press]], the [[Fantasy Press (UK)|Fantasy Press]], the [[Kit-Cat Press]], [[Big Wheel Press]], the [[Perpetua Press]], the [[Incline Press]], the [[Whittington Press]], the [[Libanus Press]], the [[Rocket Press]], the [[Stanbrook Abbey]] Press and the [[Officina Bodoni|Stamperia Valdonega]].<ref>Nash and Howes 2006, plates 1-4 and pp. 25-180.</ref>
After a period of difficulties and disrupted activities in the last decade of the twentieth century, the Society closed in 2000, when interest among the students had declined so far that a junior committee could no longer be formed. However, due to the efforts of a new generation of Oxford students led by Geri Della Rocca de Candal, Enrico Emanuele Prodi and Matthew Cheung Salisbury, aided by Cristina Dondi, [[Richard Ovenden]] and a few surviving members of the former Society (notably [[Colin Franklin (writer and bibliographer)|Colin Franklin]] and Paul W. Nash), the Oxford University Society of Bibliophiles was refounded in [[Trinity term]] 2008 and became fully active in [[Michaelmas term]] in the same year. The first termcard for the new Society was printed by the Rampant Lions Press (and was among the last jobs printed by Sebastian Carter).
The Society's device, shown opposite, was designed by [[Michael Harvey (lettering artist)|Michael Harvey]].
==Presidents of the revived Society [2008-present]==

Collins, [[St Anne's College, Oxford|St Anne's]] - Michaelmas 1984 * T.N. Stokes, [[Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford|Lady Margaret Hall]] - Hilary and Trinity 1985 * A.E.M. Shell, [[St Hilda's College, Oxford|St Hilda's]] - Michaelmas 1985 to Trinity 1986 * H.M. Gould, [[Regent's Park College, Oxford|Regent's Park]] - Michaelmas 1986 * Christopher Shell, Balliol - Hilary 1987 * Michael Winship, Pembroke - Trinity 1987 * Simon Pulleyn, Balliol - Michaelmas 1987 to Trinity 1988 * Scott Mandelbrote, St John's - Michaelmas 1988 to Michaelmas 1989 * Adam Brown, Balliol - Hilary to Michaelmas 1990 * Neill Walker, Balliol - Hilary 1991 to Hilary 1992 * Paul W. Nash, [[Bodleian Library]] - Trinity and Michaelmas 1993 * Ben Fender, Balliol - Trinity 1994 to Trinity 1995 * K.E. Macnab, [[Pusey House]] - Michaelmas 1995 to Hilary 1998 * Thomas V. Drastik, St Edmund Hall - Trinity 1998 * Will Eckhert, [[Trinity College, Oxford|Trinity]] - Michaelmas 1998 to Trinity 2000

revision.comment: /* What makes a good performance surface */
revision.text:
A '''performance surface''' is a [[flooring]] suitable for dance or sport. Performance surfaces are normally laid on top of, or are part of, a [[sprung floor]] to produce a complete [[:wikt:dance floor|dance floor]] or [[Floor (gymnastics)|sports floor]].
Dance performance surfaces made of sheet [[Polyvinyl chloride|vinyl]] are also called '''dance floors''' and '''marley floors'''. They are called marley-type floors from a very popular reversible vinyl flooring manufactured for years until about 1978 by Marley Floors Ltd.<ref>[http://flooradvice.com/faqs/ Entertainment Flooring Systems] Frequently Asked Questions</ref>
Theatres often have a number of roll-out floors with different characteristics to satisfy the requirements of different forms of dance.
This article deals mainly with the customization of a floor for different activities by the use of different surfaces. The [[sprung floor]] article deals with the basic requirements and construction of floors to make them suitable for dance and indoor sports.
== Requirements ==
The [[sprung floor]] article outlines some of the different standards with regards to the performance surface of a sports floor. Below are some of the key factors that can influence the performance surface required within a sports facility.<ref>[http://dynamiksportsfloors.co.uk/pdf/sports-flooring-systems/Dynamik-Sports-Floors-Academy-Brochure.pdf Dynamik Sports] Academy Floor</ref> * Shock absorption: The amount of an impact that is absorbed by the floor (Usually measured in %) * Vertical deformation: The average distance the floor deforms under impact (Usually measured in mm) * Rolling load: If the floor can withstand a weighted trolley being wheeled across the surface (A set weight is defined and the outcome is usually yes/no or pass/fail) * Ball rebound: How much a ball bounces off the surface compared to what it would when being bounced on a concrete surface (Measured as a % against the bounce on a concrete surface) * Slip resistance: The level of grip the surface has (Measurements vary depending on standards)
A sprung floor with a hard surface provides protection from serious injuries rather than minor injuries. A fall can still cause bruises. A soft performance surface on the other hand can provide protection from minor injuries but not serious injuries. Providing sufficient protection from serious injury for adults using a thick performance surface alone would render it unsuitable for most dance or sport. This is because a performance surface is point elastic whereas area elasticity as provided by a sprung floor is mainly preferred.
== Traction ==
In general, dance requires less traction than gym. However a floor should not of itself be very slippery or sticky. [[DIN 18032]] defines a range of traction which should suit most activities. These type of floors should also be smooth, and a slide should not cause [[carpet burn]]. This means it is difficult to stop them from becoming slippery when wet.<ref>[http://www.ukslipresistance.org.uk/index.php?id=faqs UK Slip resistance group FAQ]</ref>
Most of the differences between the different disciplines can and should be catered for by the use of appropriate shoes. On the same surface, a dance shoe with a leather or suede sole will give much less traction than a gym shoe with a composite rubber sole. A sticky floor used for gym is very likely to cause twisted ankles, and a slippery floor used for dancing is liable to cause bad falls.
Everyday footwear nowadays tends to have a higher traction. For occasions like weddings, where the dancers may not have proper footwear, a slightly slippier floor could compensate somewhat, but a highly polished floor can be very dangerous with leather soles. Both gyms and dance clubs are better off providing good safe floors and encouraging the use of proper footwear.
== Performance surface construction ==
The performance surface is normally of [[Polyvinyl chloride|vinyl]] or [[hardwood]], [[engineered wood]] or [[laminate]]. For dance the surface may be replaceable so for instance a theatre can adapt easily to either [[ballet]] or [[tap dance]], these are normally made of vinyl sheeting. Hardwood is however preferred for tap dance.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usatap.org/aft.htm |title=National Tap Ensemble: Appropriate Flooring for Tap Dancers |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612003533/http://www.usatap.org/aft.htm |archivedate=12 June 2010}}</ref> Some sports have extra requirements like spike resistance or a standard ball bounce.<ref>[http://www.sportengland.org/facilities__planning/idoc.ashx?docid=2d9f4431-562d-4efd-af4d-6f052c9c305b&version=2 British Sports Council: Floors for Indoor Sports. Design Guidance Note]</ref>
Roll-up vinyl sheeting normally consists of:
* A thin top wear layer that also has [[UV light]] protection. Ultraviolet light rapidly degrades vinyl. This layer has to provide the proper traction and tends to be matte rather than shiny as for domestic vinyl. * A layer of vinyl which supports the wear layer. This also provides the main colour. * A woven fibre interlayer. This stops the floor deforming and also provides some area elasticity. * A bottom layer of foamed vinyl which provides the softness.
When rolled up the vinyl should not be bent sharply - it should be on rolls. When there are a number of different surfaces for a hall these can be kept on special storage carts which keep them separate rather than lying on each other.
== What makes a good performance surface ==
A wood surface is ideal for social dancing if maintained properly and is also standard for many indoor sports. [[Engineered wood]] is normally used nowadays for [[wood flooring]] as it is less liable to warp or shrink and is more economic. [[Tap dance]] is especially punishing and a tough [[hardwood]] surface like [[oak]] or [[maple]] is preferred for any regular use.
Vinyl is a better choice for other types of dance or more general community use. The requirements for different types of dance are different, but the differences can mostly be accommodated by changes in the dance surface. For instance [[Riverdance]] requires a harder surface that makes a sound, [[Ballet]] requires a softer surface because of the high jumps and possibility of falls. [[Ballroom dancing]] requires less traction than [[Scottish country dancing]].
It used to be difficult to maintain a wood floor properly. However, if the directions of the floor manufacturer are followed properly modern treatments will maintain a good surface.<ref>[http://www.bona.com/global/global/Products/Professional/Finishing__Coatings/Sportive_Systems/ Bona Sportive System] A wood floor maintenance system supporting DIN 18032:2</ref> It is important not to just trust a commercial office cleaner to know how to do a good job, they should be instructed to follow the directions. There are no cheap and foolproof machines around for measuring traction which would enable cleaners to see their work conforms to dance or sports requirements.<ref>[http://www.hse.gov.uk/pubns/web/slips01.pdf Assessing the slip resistance of flooring] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080727113054/http://www.hse.gov.uk/pubns/web/slips01.pdf |date=2008-07-27 }}</ref><ref>[http://englishxl.com/myth.html Ten Myths Concerning Slip-Resistance Measurement]</ref> Thus there is a very strong inclination for managers or cleaners to go for other requirements e.g. a shiny surface or one that resists dirt better.
If a floor is occasionally used for public events, e.g. a gym hall used for a graduation ceremony, then a [[gym floor cover]] can be used to protect the floor and ease the normal requirements.
To maintain good traction it is important to stop the floor getting dirty or even slightly wet. A good [[floor cleaning]] regime and insisting on sports or dance shoes will help with this. The main protection though is to ensure the hall has industrial grade barrier [[mat]]ting at the entrance. The building should also have a floor [[grating|grate]] at the entrance.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Dance equipment]] [[Category:Dance and health]] [[Category:Floors]] [[Category:Sports equipment]]
